intro: Eryngium cervantesii, commonly known as the Chihuahuan desert thistle, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its spiny, blue to purple flower heads. The plant has basal leaves that are typically gray-green with a woolly texture, adapted to reduce water loss in its harsh environment. Eryngium cervantesii produces small, white to yellow florets surrounded by a dense ring of bracts, which give it a distinctive appearance. It is often found in rocky soils and is an important component of the local flora in its native habitat.
